ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Samara Meade Brock  Samara Brock

Instructor: Samara Meade Brock  Samara is awesome! She's excellent at pushing her students to meet high expectations, and gives detailed and considered feedback that helps student learning. She does a really good job of facilitating classroom discussion, too.

Instructor: Samara Meade Brock  Samara was incredibly organized in facilitating this class but it should be noted that Mark Bomford was presented to the class as a teaching fellow and unlike Samara, lectured the class several times.
Instructor: Samara Meade Brock  Samara Brock (that's kind of a weird question as there's only one option provided)
Instructor: Samara Meade Brock  Samara was great. She gave me some extra ideas/suggestions for my paper, which I really appreciated. I wish we could have learned what her research was earlier on!

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Samara Meade Brock  Samara was great! She gives very detailed feedback on panel discussion, assignments and project proposal. Overall, very helpful and friendly.

Instructor: Samara Meade Brock  Strengths: Depth of knowledge, ability to bring a wide range of speakers to class, ability to connect topics. Weaknesses: must get better at cutting people off when their presentations run too long!

Instructor: Samara Meade Brock  This was a strange course, Samaras way of putting so many themes in the field with very good guests was amazing, greetings for her!. but maybe we had fewer chances to interact and discussion, maybe she need to be more strict on time management. But I appreciate the dedication and professionalism.

Instructor: Samara Meade Brock  Samara was fantastic in communicating course expectations, facilitating logistics and course discussion, and providing assignment feedback. She really helped foster an engaging community within this intimate class.

Instructor: Samara Meade Brock  Samara did a nice job of identifying interesting guest speakers and organizing their visits. I would have liked to have had her actually teach some class sessions, as her questions to speakers were always very interesting and smart.
Instructor: Samara Meade Brock  Samara is a fantastic TF, I found her extremely smart, knowledgable and approachable. I would recommend her very strongly.
Instructor: Samara Meade Brock  The classes were led by students and when the discussion fell short or silent, Samara would sometimes jump in and ask a question.

Instructor: Samara Meade Brock  Great teacher and very knowledgeable. Unfortunately as the class was so dense with visiting speakers, and two other full professors, she was given limited opportunity to shine. That was a shame as when she did have the floor she provided fascinating insights into the material and subject matter, and a needed perspective.
Instructor: Samara Meade Brock  Interesting discussion facilitation and great speakers that I believe she organized! I did not interact with her beyond weekly classes
Instructor: Samara Meade Brock  Samara is very knowledgeable about the subject matter. She was accessible. She explained projects clearly and her expectations were clear from the beginning.

Instructor: Samara Meade Brock  Samara is a great teacher, facilitator, and has an deep knowledge of many different facets and elements of food systems. As a teacher, she is open, makes important and helpful suggestions about sources and angles to take, and was the mainstay of the course.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Gordon was the professor, but the man behind the class was Mark. Mark did an excellent job at bringing complex conversations up and boiling them down to their most important elements. Gordon was more of a bystander.
Mark Bomford was also an instructor for the course. I tremendously valued his lectures and support of class discussion. Would rate him a 1 on all above metrics.

Courses on the environmental impacts of food production and alternative food production methods that are being designed to avert those problems are really important at FES. What is needed, however, are courses that go in depth, rather than repeated courses that are surveys of problems without in-depth inquiries into solutions. This was a solid survey course.
Gordon is the instructor but not *really* -- Mark lectured, Samara ran all the logistics, and we had guest speakers every week.

This was a high level course and felt a bit more geared toward a PhD audience than a Master audience. This was the first course I have taken in food systems and at times, I felt as though I would have benefitted from more previous knowledge of the subject. Specifically, I would like to point out that lectures of Mark Bomford. He is an incredible wealth of information and I learned a lot from him and his approach, but his lectures were at times over my head and I found it hard to follow his thought process. Regarding the lectures from the visiting speakers, I think those lecture were much more accessible and helped me learn about food systems on the whole. I do wish that we had more time to discuss what we learned from the different speakers, as a class, to debrief and hash out ideas.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Mark's lectures. They would have been more valuable if they had been interspersed among the guests, though.
The topics were extremely interesting and the material of study and lecturer guests very interesting also..

The selection and organization of guest speakers (e.g. panel style with student introductions and questions) was so well run, academically stimulating, and actionable. We were also heavily supported by Gordon, Mark, and Samara in our final semester projects. As a School of Management MBA student, I would also comment that the class was extremely welcoming and approachable for non-FES students interested in the covered topics. This was my favorite and most rewarding course of the semester and one of my tops for my entire Yale graduate experience.
Guest speakers.

This course's strength is in its presentation of varied approaches to food systems change. The course takes care to send a message that there is no one "right" way to go about change, but that many working on concert are valuable. This is a unique perspective to get from a class at Yale.

This class is a survey course, providing a superficial introduction to many topics and not going into depth on many topics. It is structured around a guest lecture series, which is fantastic in terms of meeting individuals and practitioners in fields that one might be interested in, but hard when not having any depth to the global food system frameworks/theories presented.

The various avenues of the food sector that were explored with fascinating guests. It's difficult to compress all of the various subjects covered though as any one week could arguably be expanded into a course/study in itself. As well it's such a vast subject that there could be more subjects and depths included, although that might need a year.
Diversity of speakers
I loved covering a wide range of subjects and having the opportunity to discuss in depth with the guest speakers.

The wide range of visiting speakers that Samara got to come to our class to present. The best part was the way in which students acted as interviewers to the speakers after they finished their lectures, also allowing for students to ask questions after the interview. This was an incredible way to learn and I felt engaged the entire time. I have never had a class that used this method and I would recommend it for other classes that utilize guest lecturers as well.

The prefacing of the course through the question of values and differing perspectives on food systems, why the plural is used in systems, and why the instructors take this approach. The different perspectives of the guest speakers and the ways in which we were asked to seriously consider their attitudes, approaches, and perspectives within food systems created the possibility of real conversation and engagement with differing ideas of the problems and solutions.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The homework assignments. They were due too early, sometimes felt like busy work, and rarely provided actual engagement while online (though were useful for class discussions).
Time management and discussion time.

I would have loved to do an optional field trip or two - e.g. the Yale farm, a community garden, a food lab, etc. We could see tangible examples of some of our course topics and have further discussion.

THE CANVAS QUESTIONS. The intention of the canvas questions needs to be clarified. If you're looking to see if we did the readings, great. If you're asking us to pose questions to the guest lecturer, great. Fusing those two intentions made the exercise tedious, and resulted in a product that seemed useless to the guest lecturer. Not to mention the Monday class to posting Thursday deadline was hard to meet.
So many moving parts that there was rarely time to digest and comprehend all the information.
I would have liked to have some continuation from session to session, some discussion sessions for just the class students to bridge the different topics covered by the external speakers.
I would have liked more opportunity for discussion within the class (rather than just questions and interviews with guest speakers).

The reading responses for each week were due the same week as class and this made it very difficult to get through the extraordinary amount of dense reading and also synthesize it into a reading response. We brought this up in class one day, as well as through emails I believe, but the professors did not feel they could change the due dates of the reading responses. This aspect of class made it hard for me to keep up with the pace and unfortunately made me fall behind at times. The course dealt with very dense material and at times very cutting-edge material and it would have been nice to have more time to digest the information and get the reading response submitted on time. Also, the aforementioned aspect of the lectures of Mark Bomford.
Encouraging more student discussion and debate; rather than listing so many readings, required and recommended, select a few that go more deeply into a particular topic.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Very effective, although dense. One possible future experiment would be to see if the focus for one subject were expanded to two weeks, wherein the class could have a prior discussion to the subject of the upcoming visiting speaker, or vice versi.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: For an Agronomist that is on the entrepreneur side, it is extremely important, it gave me a completely different overview of food systems and how to approach to the future..

I am passionate about policy reform and private sector involvement to drive economic inclusion and development. Topics of food security, food pricing and access, community gardening, and agriculture industry topics (including supply chain, food retail, and rural livelihoods) were extremely relevant for my current and future endeavors.

As a student interested in studying food systems, this is an essential class. Sadly, there is not yet an undergrad or graduate food program, so it doesn't "fit" in that way. It does help inform what I want to do after graduation though.
There are very few food classes offered at Yale and as someone interested in food issues, it seemed like a good class to take.

Food systems are related to many aspects of environmental management, from environmental health to ecosystem conservation to climate change. I took this course because it is one of the few offered on 'sustainable' food and agriculture, which is an underrepresented area at FES which most students must cobble together based on FES and non-FES courses.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted a survey-level understanding of the issues in an industry I've always been curious about.
See above Question 20.
I'm interested in food issues.
1) Mark and Samara and geniuses. 2)Trying to take all the food courses I can. 3) To learn about systems change.
I took this class for the exposure to guest lecturers and overview of food system approaches.
Interest.
I wanted to broaden my knowledge in the global food systems and surveying this course seemed like an excellent opportunity to do so.
I wanted to learn more about how global food systems work and the intricacies of the supply chains of the products we eat every day and how they are monitored and regulated.
To gain a better understanding of contemporary food and agriculture and the issues and debates within the community of people and experts who are addressing challenges and solutions.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Knowledge about food systems gained from the course exceeded my expectations.
Yes, completely
Met and far surpassed my expectations. See above Question 20.
In all honesty, no. There was no cohesion between the guest lectures. Mark's lectures for example could have been interspersed and been the space to contextualize these solutions.
Yes.
To an extent yes, although I would have liked more time to relate the different topics presented to topics of student interest or our wider program.
To a certain degree, yes, but it was a bit difficult to get a good sense of any of the individual topics because of the wide range of topics covered.
Yes, although I would have liked to go more deeply into particular topics and have more than one class on, for example, agroecology.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Advantage is to share different opinions with my classmates. I don't see disadvantages

The final project was to be done either individually or in a group and I appreciated that the professors left this open. I decided to work in a group with one other student and it ended up being a good experience. Both of us brought distinct background knowledge to the project and it allowed us to develop a unique project and I therefore learned more than had I worked alone.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Prepare to read and to share with extremely wise professors.
Take the course! You'll love the content, structure, professors, guest speakers as well as classmates (self-selected for students interested in these fascinating and applicable topics).
The class is what you make it. Make sure you're clear in what you are hoping to gain.
Take it if your curious about various aspects of the world's food system, and the potential ramifications of them.
Take it.
